detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Principles and Practice of costume design for the theatre. The design process and the practical aspects of costume production will be examined in detail. The course will also examine the meaning and purpose of costume in a theatrical and film production.
Students will explore an approach to textual analysis and visual research for the designer. Drawing and rendering for costume design will be an ongoing activity.

If this section if FULL or BLOCKED please sign up for the corresponding waitlist section. Once you have registered in the wait list there is no need to contact the department. Your registration will be switched to the parent section when space becomes available. Preference may be given to Majors, Minors, or Honours students in Theatre or Film. For more information about Department of Theatre and Film wait lists please visit: http://theatrefilm.ubc.ca/undergraduate/undergraduate-courses/how-to-wait-list-a-course/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: THTR 310 Theories of Drama, Theatre, and Performance In this course we explore critical concepts from theatre and performance theories that have influenced production and reception practices in a range of global performance contexts. As comprehensive coverage of the vast array of such theories is impossible in a single class, we aim here to build critical vocabulary for analysing contemporary theatre and performance in relation to the politics of embodiment, space, media, race, gender, class, and ability.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: THTR 311: Intercultural Theatre:Interculturalism, as Canadas leading theatre scholar Ric Knowles argues, is an urgent topic in the twenty-first century as it becomes imperative that the ways in which cultural exchange is performed be critically re-examined. This course examines the historical and contemporary practices and critical debates of intercultural performance. Topics include: pre- and early-20th century European encounters with Asian theatre, intercultural theatre productions and debates of the 1980s and 1990s, Asian Shakespeare productions, and contemporary intercultural performance in North America. We will approach these issues through a combination of lectures, discussions, video production viewings, reaction papers, and group projects.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as in-person are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to Waitlist and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

instances.text: UFOR_V 316-101 - Trees and Shrubs in Landscape

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Investigation of contemporary practices in sculpture and the use of scale. Emphasis on public sculpture. The course focuses on producing 3D work in relation to public space. It includes technical instruction in typical industrial materials and methods used to construct the world around us. Students are expected to do significant amounts of hands-on exercises and production in the shop, to participate in field work, and to produce two works for public spaces.

Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
